awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Experimental Techniques for Discerning Female-specific Morphology in Non-avian Theropod Dinosaurs
awd_abstract_narration:
Birds include more species than in any other group of extant vertebrates, and were the only lineage of dinosaurs to survive the mass extinction at the end of the Cretaceous Period about 65 million years ago. The long-standing success of birds may be attributable in part to their unique reproductive physiology, which includes a specialized skeletal tissue deposited in the inner cavity of long bones known as medullary bone (MB). MB acts as a calcium reserve for the production of eggshells and was long thought to be a key reproductive adaptation unique to birds. However, the tissue has recently been purported to occur in a handful of extinct species, including both non-avian dinosaurs and dinosaurian relatives. Given the vast evolutionary distance across the groups in which MB has been tentatively identified (across lineages that diverged over 100 million years prior to the origin of birds), substantiation (or refutation) of MB in these taxa and a careful study of the chemical characteristics and microstructure of these skeletal tissues is a critical first step to determine the validity of these identifications and the evolutionary significance of this tissue. The proposed project will be transformative in developing an untested, independent proxy for chemically distinguishing MB in fossils, and a non-destructive means for identifying the microstructure of MB in the fossil record that can be used to explore reproductive life history and physiology of the bird lineage in deep time. Public outreach and education associated with this research will be conducted at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. 

Medullary bone (MB) is an ephemeral, estrogen dependent, endosteal tissue lining the marrow cavity in extant avialans (birds). This specialized reproductive tissue is highly vascular histologically, exhibits a woven bone matrix, and is more densely mineralized than other bone types. Although originally considered a key avian adaptation, MB has since been identified in non-avian theropod and ornithopod dinosaurs, far removed phylogenetically from the direct lineage of extant avialans, and most recently outside of Dinosauria, in one of the clade's closest extinct relatives Pterosauria (non-dinosaurian flying reptiles). To date, identifications of MB in fossils have relied exclusively on structural comparisons (location, texture, distribution, and microstructure) with MB in birds by means of histological (destructive) sampling. However, MB in living birds can also be identified by its unique molecular signature because the tissue incorporates more non-collagenous proteins than cortical bone, and utilizes more sulfated glycosaminoglycans, particularly keratan sulfate, which is not present in cortical bone. This project will provide new information on chemical and microstructural variation in MB within extant avialans and will use these data to generate novel µCT and histochemical techniques for identifying MB in the fossil record. This protocol will then be used to test the homology of published accounts of MB in extinct Archosauria, ultimately providing an informed phylogenetic context for the evolution of medullary bone and avian-specific reproductive physiology. This research is co-funded through the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering in support of research on fossils in China and Mongolia in this project.

por.por_cntn:
The ability for scientists to determine the biological sex of fossil skeletons would revolutionize our understanding of dinosaur ecology and evolution. However, to date, discriminating male and female morphs has proven difficult, and only a handful of fossil dinosaur specimens bearing eggs or follicles within the body cavity at the time of death, can be definitively recognized as female. Given the rarity of such preservation, robust skeletal indicators of biological sex are needed to advance studies of dinosaurian reproductive biology. 

One such possibility is an ephemeral, sex-specific skeletal tissue observed in living dinosaurs (birds) that functions as a mineral reservoir for shelling eggs, known as medullary bone (MB). When detected, the presence of MB unequivocally identifies the skeletal remains as those of a reproductively active female. To date, MB-like tissues have been identified in a handful of fossil specimens including extinct birds, non-avian theropod dinosaurs, ornithopod dinosaurs, and pterosaurs. However, the nature of these MB-like tissues remains controversial. Given the large taxonomic breadth for which MB has been tentatively identified (across clades that diverged over 100 million years prior to the origin of birds), verification (or refutation) of MB in these taxa is key to understanding when MB originated during the evolution of vertebrate life and what advantages it might have conveyed.

In order to evaluate the hypothesis of MB in extinct species, previous researchers have proposed a series of morphological and chemical criteria unique to MB. However, these criteria were based on an incomplete knowledge of the variability and distribution of MB in living birds. Our prior understanding of avian MB derived from a subsample of avian species relevant to the poultry industry or hormonally treated males, which failed to capture variation associated with the range of physiologies and ecologies encountered in wild bird species. With this award we set out to create a foundational understanding of the morphological and chemical variability in avian MB, improve the analytical approaches available for identifying MB in both living and extinct species including discriminating MB from pathological bone (PB), and ultimately advance the discourse on identifying MB in extant birds and their extinct relatives. 

We find MB to be a systemic tissue that can be deposited within virtually all skeletal regions, including cranial elements, and note it is uniformly present in the tibiotarsus, providing a best-practice protocol for sampling MB in the avian skeleton. We therefore refute previous research attempting to invalidate MB identifications in fossil specimens based on skeletal location. We also find that MB has a chemical signature distinct from normal cortical bone, specifically, that keratan sulfate is a reliable chemical marker of MB that should form one criterion for identifying this tissue in fossil specimens. However, our data also reveal that most PB tissues also contain keratan sulfate, thus the detection of this biomarker is not adequate by itself, to discriminate between MB and all PB tissues. Our methodological advancements include: 1) documenting that CT scanning is a reliable method for assessing the skeletal distribution of MB in avian specimens; and 2) documenting that keratan sulfate can be detected in living bird and fossil specimens via histochemical and immunochemical analyses. 

Our broader results inform on the reproductive and evolutionary significance of MB. We document that MB is present universally in all birds tested and that its distribution in the avian skeleton is linked to ecology. Birds exhibiting ecological extremes, such as high efficiency flyers and ground-dwelling species, large and small bodied species, birds with high dietary calcium intake, and those with thickened bone cortices related to semiaquatic lifestyles, all deposit MB; none have evolutionarily lost the ability to produce MB. We also document that MB skeletal distribution follows predictable patterns. The skeletal distribution of MB is directly related to the distribution of red bone marrow, and inversely correlated to the combined distributions of pneumaticity and yellow bone marrow. This provides the only unique criterion that can definitively discriminate between MB and PB in fossil specimens known to date. Our comparative investigation of MB microstructural variability across birds indicates that microstructure is predominantly uniform. However, we note that a lamellar component is present in some of the most primitive birds, and may be indicative of the ancestral morphology of MB among non-avian dinosaurs. Taken together, our results provide a refined set of criteria for testing purported hypotheses of MB-like tissues in extinct species and a more comprehensive understanding of the morphological and chemical variability in the reproductive tissues of living birds. 

Finally, we disseminated our results widely to the general public, reaching a combined audience of >3,000, and hosted a three-day paleohistology workshop to train students and early career researchers in petrographic ground section techniques and the interpretation of histological data. As a result we have generated institution-wide growth in expertise in paleohistological techniques at several American universities.
